case_vignette: Three days after undergoing open surgery to repair a bilateral inguinal hernia, a 66-year-old man has new, intermittent upper abdominal discomfort that worsens when he walks around! He also has new shortness of breath that resolves with rest! There were no complications during surgery or during the immediate postsurgical period! Ambulation was restarted on the first postoperative day! He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension! He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years! Prior to admission, his medications included metformin, simvastatin, and lisinopril! His temperature is 37°C (98!6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 129/80 mm Hg! Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%! The abdomen is soft and shows two healing surgical scars with moderate serous discharge! Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities! An ECG at rest shows no abnormalities! Cardiac enzyme levels are within the reference range! An x-ray of the chest and abdominal ultrasonography show no abnormalities!
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have been experiencing upper abdominal discomfort that gets worse when I walk and shortness of breath that goes away when I rest.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have been experiencing these symptoms for three days.
Do you have any existing medical conditions like hypertension, diabetes, or high cholesterol?
Yes, I have type 2 diabetes, high cholesterol, and hypertension.
Are you currently on any medications for your conditions? If so, what are they?
Yes, I am taking metformin for diabetes, simvastatin for high cholesterol, and lisinopril for hypertension.
Have you noticed any swelling in your legs or feet recently?
No, I have not noticed any swelling in my legs or feet.
Do you have a family history of heart disease?
I'm sorry, but I don't have information about my family history of heart disease.
Do you experience any pain in your chest, particularly during physical activity or stress?
No, I do not experience any chest pain during physical activity or stress.
Have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, or sweating along with your current symptoms?
No, I have not experienced any nausea, vomiting, or sweating with my current symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Angina Pectoris

The patient has type 2 diabetes, high cholesterol, and hypertension, and has been treating these conditions with metformin, simvastatin, and lisinopril respectively. The patient has not observed any swelling in the legs or feet, and does not have information about a family history of heart disease. Furthermore, the patient does not endure chest pain during physical activity or stress, nor has the patient reported experiencing any nausea, vomiting, or sweating in conjunction with the current symptoms.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is an exercise stress test.
